algorithms.statistics

Class Gamma

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.statistics.Gamma

  • public class Gamma
extends java.lang.Object
    Calculates the gamma function using the Lancos approximation. Gamma(x) = integral( t^(x-1) e^(-t), t = 0 .. infinity) The code below is copied from https://web.archive.org/web/20170118064524/http://blog.javia.org/docs/Gamma.java which is a web archive of the page at http://blog.javia.org/docs/Gamma.java The copyrights are: Author Mihai Preda, 2006. The author disclaims copyright to this source code. The method lgamma() is adapted from FDLIBM 5.3 (http://www.netlib.org/fdlibm/), which comes with this copyright notice: ==================================================== Copyright (C) 1993 by Sun Microsystems, Inc. All rights reserved. Developed at SunSoft, a Sun Microsystems, Inc. business. Permission to use, copy, modify, and distribute this software is freely granted, provided that this notice is preserved. ==================================================== The Lanczos and Stirling approximations are based on: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lanczos_approximation http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stirling%27s_approximation http://www.gnu.org/software/gsl/ http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/math/ http://my.fit.edu/~gabdo/gamma.txt helpful non-open source code: https://introcs.cs.princeton.edu/java/91float/Gamma.java.html The gamma distribution follows wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution

      • gammaScaleDistributionPDF

        public static double gammaScaleDistributionPDF(double x,
                                               double shape,
                                               double scale)
        NOT YET TESTED < Γ > the gamma distribution is a two-parameter family of continuous probability distributions. The exponential distribution, Erlang distribution, and chi-squared distribution are special cases of the gamma distribution. There are three different parameterizations in common use: 
                1) With a shape parameter k and a scale parameter θ.
        2) With a shape parameter α = k and an inverse scale parameter β = 1/θ, 
           called a rate parameter.
        3) With a shape parameter k and a mean parameter μ = kθ = α/β.
 following https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution
        Parameters:
        x -
        shape -
        scale -
        Returns:

      • gammaRateDistributionPDF

        public static double gammaRateDistributionPDF(double x,
                                              double shape,
                                              double rate)
        NOT YET TESTED < Γ > the gamma distribution is a two-parameter family of continuous probability distributions. The exponential distribution, Erlang distribution, and chi-squared distribution are special cases of the gamma distribution. There are three different parameterizations in common use: 
                1) With a shape parameter k and a scale parameter θ.
        2) With a shape parameter α = k and an inverse scale parameter β = 1/θ, 
           called a rate parameter.
        3) With a shape parameter k and a mean parameter μ = kθ = α/β.
 following https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_distribution
